verses.text: All wisdom comes from the Lord, and with Him it remains forever.
verses.comment: This verse connects God's wisdom directly to Himself, highlighting that true wisdom is a divine attribute. The eternal nature of wisdom aligns with the central Christological theme that Christ is the wisdom and Word of God (see 1 Cor. 1:24; John 1:1).

verses.text: Who can count the sand of the sea, the drops of rain, or the days of eternity?
verses.comment: By listing uncountable things, Sirach points to God's unlimited knowledge and the mystery of eternity, which human wisdom cannot attain apart from divine revelation.

verses.text: Who can find out the height of heaven, the breadth of the earth, the depth of the abyss, or wisdom?
verses.comment: Compares the unknowability of natural phenomena with wisdom, reinforcing that only God fully possesses and reveals true wisdom.

verses.text: Wisdom was created before all things, and the understanding of prudence from everlasting.
verses.comment: This mirrors the 'Wisdom' personified in Proverbs, prefiguring the eternal Word—suggesting a connection between divine Wisdom and Christ. Early Christians saw in these words a prophecy of Christ's pre-existence.

verses.text: The source of wisdom is the word of God in heaven, and her ways are eternal commandments.
verses.comment: Wisdom's source is God's spoken word. This highlights the importance of divine revelation and the authority of sacred instruction, laying a strong foundation for later Christian teaching on doctrine and tradition from God.

verses.text: To whom has the root of wisdom been revealed, and who has understood her great deeds?
verses.comment: The root of wisdom is a mystery revealed only to those whom God chooses, emphasizing the necessity of humility before divine teaching and revelation.

verses.text: There is One who is wise and greatly to be feared, sitting upon His throne.
verses.comment: Only God Himself is the ultimate source of wisdom. The throne imagery reminds us of God’s sovereign rule and the heavenly court.

verses.text: The Lord Himself created wisdom; He saw her and measured her, and poured her out upon all His works.
verses.comment: This verse presents wisdom as both created and overflowing into creation, paralleling the Christian understanding of God’s order and the role of the divine Logos as mediator in the world.

verses.text: He poured her out upon all flesh according to His gift, and gave her to those who love Him.
verses.comment: Wisdom is offered universally but especially given to those who are in a relationship of love and obedience to the Lord. This recalls God’s desire to share His gifts widely through divine grace.

verses.text: Fear of the Lord is glory and pride, joy and a crown of rejoicing.
verses.comment: The fear of the Lord is foundational for all wisdom, leading to glory, honor, and spiritual joy. In the spiritual sense, a crown points to eternal reward (James 1:12; Rev. 2:10).

verses.text: The fear of the Lord delights the heart and brings gladness, joy, and long life.
verses.comment: Godly fear is not terror but reverence, leading to a joyful, fulfilled life — a theme echoed throughout Scripture and especially in the Beatitudes (Matt. 5:3-12).

verses.text: Whoever fears the Lord will have a prosperous end; he will be blessed in the day of his death.
verses.comment: An allusion to the promise of future blessing, even after death—hinting at the hope for eternal life.

verses.text: To fear the Lord is the beginning of wisdom; it was created with the faithful in the womb.
verses.comment: Wisdom and the fear of the Lord are inseparable, and God imparts this even before birth. This has important implications for theology of God's providence and the sanctity of every human life.

verses.text: She has made her dwelling among mankind; she is a foundation for everlasting offspring.
verses.comment: Wisdom dwelling among people points to the incarnation of the Word. The phrase ‘foundation for everlasting offspring’ hints at the continuity of God’s covenant people.

verses.text: To fear the Lord is fullness of wisdom; she fills them with her fruits.
verses.comment: The fruitfulness of wisdom parallels the fruit of the Spirit. Reverence toward God naturally leads to virtuous living and spiritual abundance.

verses.text: She will fill their entire house with desirable things, and their storerooms with her produce.
verses.comment: Wisdom brings fullness and blessing to the believer’s life—both spiritual and material—hearkening to God’s promise to prosper the righteous.

verses.text: The fear of the Lord is the crown of wisdom, causing peace and perfect health to flourish.
verses.comment: The crowning of wisdom with peace and health recalls the holistic blessings God gives to those who live according to His ways.

verses.text: She rained down knowledge and understanding, and exalted the glory of those who hold to her.
verses.comment: Wisdom leads to knowledge, understanding, and spiritual elevation. Implies the transforming effect of divine teaching in the believer’s life.

verses.text: To fear the Lord is the root of wisdom, and her branches are long life.
verses.comment: Just as a tree’s root gives life, so the fear of the Lord anchors wisdom and produces lasting spiritual vitality.

verses.text: Unrighteous anger cannot be justified, for a man’s wrath tips him toward his downfall.
verses.comment: Warns against unjust anger. The need to master one’s passions is foundational for spiritual growth and sanctification.

verses.text: Those who are patient will hold back until the right moment, and afterwards joy will break forth for them.
verses.comment: Patience in trial brings joy in the end — the principle of awaiting God’s timing is woven throughout Scriptures.

verses.text: Until the right time, they will control their words, and the lips of many will tell of their understanding.
verses.comment: Self-restraint in speech is a sign of wisdom. Divine prudence means knowing when to speak and when to keep silent.

verses.text: The parables of knowledge are found in the treasures of wisdom; godliness is an abomination to the sinner.
verses.comment: The wise discern spiritual truth, but those far from God’s ways reject it. Jesus spoke in parables for a similar effect.

verses.text: If you desire wisdom, keep the commandments, and the Lord will supply her in abundance.
verses.comment: Active obedience leads to deeper understanding. God's grace and wisdom are intertwined with the life of obedience and faithfulness.

verses.text: For the fear of the Lord is wisdom and instruction, and faithfulness and meekness are His delight.
verses.comment: Meekness is a fruit of wisdom and a virtue highly praised by Christ, promising blessing (cf. Matthew 5:5, the Beatitudes).

verses.text: Do not disobey the fear of the Lord, and do not approach Him with a double heart.
verses.comment: Calls for integrity and a single-hearted devotion in our relationship with God, warning against hypocrisy.

verses.text: Do not be a hypocrite in men’s sight, and beware lest you fall through your lips.
verses.comment: Public hypocrisy and careless speech lead to spiritual ruin, while sincerity is always commended in the sight of God.

verses.text: Do not exalt yourself, or you may fall and bring dishonor upon yourself; the Lord will reveal your secrets and cast you down in the midst of the assembly, because you did not come in the fear of the Lord, and your heart was full of deceit.
verses.comment: Warnings against pride and spiritual duplicity, which are consistently condemned in both Old and New Testaments. Humility is preferred by God for blessing and honor.

verses.text: For wisdom will not enter a deceitful soul, nor dwell in a body enslaved to sin.
verses.comment: This verse hints at the necessity of purity for receiving spiritual gifts. Godliness and moral transformation go hand-in-hand with receiving and keeping wisdom.

verses.text: A patient man will bear for a time, and afterwards joy will arise for him.
verses.comment: Patience through trials is rewarded by God, as seen in many biblical stories. This reflects the perennial Christian call to perseverance and trust in God’s justice.
